sen.j: 杉田 玄白（すぎた げんぱく、享保18年9月13日 (旧暦)（1733年10月20日） - 文化 (元号)14年4月17日 (旧暦)（1817年6月1日））は、江戸時代の蘭学医。
sen.e: Genpaku SUGITA (October 20, 1733 - June 1, 1817) was a rangakui (a person who studied Western medicine by means of the Dutch language) during the Edo Period.
Genpaku SUGITA (October 20, 1733 - June 1, 1817) was a rangakui (a person who studied Western medicine by means of the Dutch language) during the Edo Period.
Genpaku SUGITA (October 20, 1733 - June 1, 1817) was a rangakui (a person who studied Western medicine by means of the Dutch language) during the Edo Period.

sen.j: 若狭国小浜藩（福井県）医。
sen.e: He was a doctor of the Obama Domain, Wakasa Province (Fukui Prefecture).
He was a doctor of the Obama Domain, Wakasa Province (Fukui Prefecture).
He was a doctor of the Obama Domain, Wakasa Province (Fukui Prefecture).

sen.j: 私塾天真楼を主催。
sen.e: Genpaku sponsored a private school called Tenshinro.
Genpaku sponsored a private school called Tenshinro.
Genpaku sponsored a private school called Tenshinro.

sen.j: 父は杉田玄甫、母は八尾氏の娘。
sen.e: His father was Genpo SUGITA and his mother was a daughter of the YAO clan.
sen.cmt: 杉田玄甫：読み方不明です。
sen.e: His father was Genpo SUGITA and his mother was a daughter of the YAO clan.
His father was Genpo SUGITA and his mother was a daughter of the YAO clan.

sen.j: 諱は翼（たすく）、字は子鳳、号は鷧、晩年に九幸翁。
sen.e: His imina (personal name) was Tasuku, azana (adult male's nickname)was Shiho, and go (pen name) was 鷧 (九幸翁 in his later years).
His imina (personal name) was Tasuku, azana (adult male's nickname) was Shiho, and go (pen name) was 鷧 (九幸翁 in his later years).
His imina (personal name) was Tasuku, azana (adult male's nickname) was Shiho, and go (pen name) was 鷧 (九幸翁 in his later years).

sen.j: 杉田氏は近江源氏である佐々木氏の支族である真野氏の家系。
sen.e: The SUGITA clan stemmed from the MANO clan, a branch family of the SASAKI clan (one of the OMI-GENJI clan).
The SUGITA clan stemmed from the MANO clan, a branch family of the SASAKI clan (one of the OMI-GENJI clan).
The SUGITA clan stemmed from the MANO clan, a branch family of the SASAKI clan (one of the OMI-GENJI clan).

sen.j: 後北条氏に仕えた真野信安のときに間宮姓に改め、子の長安の代に復姓。
sen.e: His ancestor, Nobuyasu MANO who served the GOHOJO clan, changed its family name to MAMIYA and Nobuyasu's son, Nagayasu MAMIYA, restored it to MANO.
His ancestor, Nobuyasu MANO who served the GOHOJO clan, changed the family name to MAMIYA and Nobuyasu's son, Nagayasu MAMIYA, restored it to MANO.
His ancestor, Nobuyasu MANO who served the GOHOJO clan, changed the family name to MAMIYA and Nobuyasu's son, Nagayasu MAMIYA, restored it to MANO.

sen.j: 医家としては、玄白で3代目にあたる。
sen.e: Genpaku is the third generation of the family to practice medicine.
Genpaku is the third generation of the family to practice medicine.
Genpaku is the third generation of the family to practice medicine.

sen.j: 同時代に活躍し、間宮海峡にその名を残す探検家である間宮林蔵は同族である。
sen.e: Rinzo MAMIYA, who was an explorer and after whom the mamiya strait was named, was from the same family as Genpaku.
Rinzo MAMIYA, who was an explorer and after whom the mamiya strait was named, was from the same family as Genpaku.
Rinzo MAMIYA, who was an explorer and after whom the mamiya strait was named, was from the same family as Genpaku.

sen.j: 江戸、牛込の小浜藩酒井家の下屋敷に生まれるが、玄白の生母は出産の際に死去している。
sen.e: Genpaku was born in the suburban residence of the SAKAI family of the Obama Domain, Ushigome, Edo, but his biological mother died while giving birth to him.
Genpaku was born in the suburban residence of the SAKAI family of the Obama Domain, Ushigome, Edo, but his biological mother died while giving birth to him.
Genpaku was born in the suburban residence of the SAKAI family of the Obama Domain, Ushigome, Edo, but his biological mother died while giving birth to him.

sen.j: 下屋敷で育ち、元文5年（1740年）には一家で小浜へ移り、父の玄甫が江戸詰めを命じられる延享2年（1745年）まで過ごす。
sen.e: After growing up in the residence, his family moved to Obama in 1740 to have spent his childhood until 1745 when his father, Genpo, was ordered to work in Edo.
After growing up in the residence, his family moved to Obama in 1740 where he spent his childhood until 1745 when his father, Genpo, was ordered to work in Edo.
After growing up in the residence, his family moved to Obama in 1740 where he spent his childhood until 1745 when his father, Genpo, was ordered to work in Edo.

sen.j: 青年期には家業の医学修行を始め、医学は奥医の西玄哲に、漢学は本郷 (文京区)に開塾していた古学派の儒者宮瀬竜門に学ぶ。
sen.e: Genpaku started learning his family business, medical science, in his adolescence; he studied western medicine under Gentetsu NISHI, a feudal doctor, and Chinese medicine under Ryumon MIYASE, a Confucian belonging to School of Ancient Learning and a founder of the medical school in Hongo (Bunkyo Ward, Tokyo).

Genpaku started learning his family business, medical science, in his adolescence; he studied western medicine under Gentetsu NISHI, a feudal doctor, and Chinese medicine under Ryumon MIYASE, a Confucian belonging to School of Ancient Learning and a founder of the medical school in Hongo (Bunkyo Ward, Tokyo).

Genpaku started learning his family business, medical science, in his adolescence; he studied western medicine under Gentetsu NISHI, a feudal doctor, and Chinese medicine under Ryumon MIYASE, a Confucian belonging to School of Ancient Learning and a founder of the medical school in Hongo (Bunkyo Ward, Tokyo).

sen.j: 宝暦2年（1752年）に小浜藩医となり、上屋敷に詰める。
sen.e: Genpaku was appointed as a doctor of the Obama Domain in 1752 and started working in the main residence of the Domain.
Genpaku was appointed as a doctor of the Obama Domain in 1752 and started working in the main residence of the Domain.
Genpaku was appointed as a doctor of the Obama Domain in 1752 and started working in the main residence of the Domain.

sen.j: 宝暦7年（1757年）には江戸、日本橋 (東京都中央区)地域としての日本橋に開業し、町医者となる。
sen.e: In 1757, he became a town doctor by opening his business in the Nihonbashi area (Chuo Ward, Tokyo).
In 1757, he became a town doctor by opening his business in the Nihonbashi area (Chuo Ward, Tokyo).
In 1757, he became a town doctor by opening his business in the Nihonbashi area (Chuo Ward, Tokyo).

sen.j: 同年7月には、江戸で博物学本草学者の田村元雄や平賀源内らが物産会を主催。
sen.e: In July the same year, Motoo TAMURA, a scholar of natural history and herbalism, and Gennai HIRAGA sponsored a Domain commodity fair in Edo.
In July the same year, Motoo TAMURA, a scholar of natural history and herbalism, and Gennai HIRAGA sponsored a Domain commodity fair in Edo.
In July the same year, Motoo TAMURA, a scholar of natural history and herbalism, and Gennai HIRAGA sponsored a Domain commodity fair in Edo.

sen.j: 出展者には中川淳庵の名も見られ、蘭学者グループの交友はこの頃にははじまっていたと思われる。
sen.e: Among the attendance was Junan NAKAGAWA, a doctor, a herbalism scholar and rangakui, indicating that Dutch scholars had already formed a good fellowship at this time of the period.
Attending was Junan NAKAGAWA, a doctor, an herbalism scholar and rangakui, indicating that Dutch scholars had already formed a good fellowship at this time.
Attending was Junan NAKAGAWA, a doctor, an herbalism scholar and rangakui, indicating that Dutch scholars had already formed a good fellowship at this time.

sen.j: 宝暦4年（1754年）には京都で山脇東洋が、処刑された罪人の腑分け（人体解剖）を実施している。
sen.e: In 1754, Toyo YAMAWAKI performed dissection of a dead body who was a criminal and executed in Kyoto.
In 1754, Toyo YAMAWAKI dissected the cadaver of a criminal who was executed in Kyoto.
In 1754, Toyo YAMAWAKI dissected the cadaver of a criminal who was executed in Kyoto.

sen.j: 国内初の人体解剖は蘭書の正確性を証明し、日本の医学界に波紋を投げかけるとともに、玄白が五臓六腑説への疑問を抱くきっかけとなる。
sen.e: The first domestic dissection proved how accurate books of western medicine were, causing repercussions for the Japanese medical circle and giving the chance for Genpaku to doubt the traditionally-supported Chinese theory that a human body consisted of five viscera (liver, lungs, heart, kidney and spleen) and six bowels (small intestine, large intestine, gall bladder, urinary bladder, stomach and san jiao).

The first domestic dissection proved how accurate books of western medicine were, causing repercussions in Japanese medical circles and giving the chance for Genpaku to doubt the traditionally-supported Chinese theory that a human body consisted of five viscera (liver, lungs, heart, kidney and spleen) and six bowels (small intestine, large intestine, gall bladder, urinary bladder, stomach and san jiao).

The first domestic dissection proved how accurate books of western medicine were, causing repercussions in Japanese medical circles and giving the chance for Genpaku to doubt the traditionally-supported Chinese theory that a human body consisted of five viscera (liver, lungs, heart, kidney and spleen) and six bowels (small intestine, large intestine, gall bladder, urinary bladder, stomach and san jiao).

sen.j: 明和2年（1765年）には藩の奥医師となる。
sen.e: Genpaku became a Domain doctor in 1765.
Genpaku became a Domain doctor in 1765.
Genpaku became a Domain doctor in 1765.

sen.j: 同年、オランダ商館長やオランダ通詞らの一行が江戸へ参府した際、玄白は源内らと一行の滞在する長崎屋源右衛門を訪問。
sen.e: When a group of a curator of Dutch trading house (the Kapitan) and Dutch translators paid a visit to the feudal government in Edo in the same year, Genpaku and Gennai HIRAGA visited the inn of Genemon NAGASAKIYA where the group was staying.

When a group of a curator of Dutch trading house (the Kapitan) and Dutch translators paid a visit to the feudal government in Edo in the same year, Genpaku and Gennai HIRAGA visited the inn of Genemon NAGASAKIYA where the group was staying.

When a group of a curator of Dutch trading house (the Kapitan) and Dutch translators paid a visit to the feudal government in Edo in the same year, Genpaku and Gennai HIRAGA visited the inn of Genemon NAGASAKIYA where the group was staying.

sen.j: 通詞の西善三郎からオランダ語学習の困難さを諭され、玄白はオランダ語習得を断念している。
sen.e: At that time, Zensaburo NISHI, a Dutch translator, admonished Genpaku against learning Dutch due to its difficulty, and Genpaku took the advice and gave up mastering the language.
At that time, Zensaburo NISHI, a Dutch translator, admonished Genpaku against learning Dutch due to its difficulty, and Genpaku took the advice and gave up mastering the language.
At that time, Zensaburo NISHI, a Dutch translator, admonished Genpaku against learning Dutch due to its difficulty, and Genpaku took the advice and gave up mastering the language.

sen.j: 明和6年（1769年）には父の玄甫が死去。
sen.e: In 1769, Genpaku's father, Genpo, died.
In 1769, Genpaku's father, Genpo, died.
In 1769, Genpaku's father, Genpo, died.

sen.j: 家督と侍医の職を継ぎ、新大橋の中屋敷へ詰める。
sen.e: Genpaku succeeded both the reigns of the family and the family business as a court physician, and started working in the second city residence of the Domain in Shinohashi.
Genpaku succeeded both the reigns of the family and the family business as a court physician, and started working in the second city residence of the Domain in Shinohashi.
Genpaku succeeded both the reigns of the family and the family business as a court physician, and started working in the second city residence of the Domain in Shinohashi.

sen.j: 明和8年（1771年）、自身の回想録である『蘭学事始』によれば、中川淳庵がオランダ商館院から借りたオランダ語医学書『ターヘル・アナトミア』をもって玄白のもとを訪れる。
sen.e: According to the "Rangaku Kotohajime" (The Beginning of Dutch Studies), Genpaku's self memoirs, Junan NAKAGAWA visited Genpaku in 1771 with a Dutch medical science book, "Ontleedkundige Tafelen", which was borrowed from the Dutch trading house.

According to the "Rangaku Kotohajime" (The Beginning of Dutch Studies), Genpaku's self memoirs, Junan NAKAGAWA visited Genpaku in 1771 with a Dutch medical science book, "Ontleedkundige Tafelen", which was borrowed from the Dutch trading house.

According to the "Rangaku Kotohajime" (The Beginning of Dutch Studies), Genpaku's self memoirs, Junan NAKAGAWA visited Genpaku in 1771 with a Dutch medical science book, "Ontleedkundige Tafelen," which was borrowed from the Dutch trading house.
sen.cmt: カンマの位置を修正しました。

sen.j: 玄白はオランダ語の本文は読めなかったものの、図版の精密な解剖図に驚き、藩に相談してこれを購入する。
sen.e: Although Genpaku could not read the book written in Dutch, he was startled with the accuracy of the anatomical chart and advised the Domain to purchase the book.
Although Genpaku could not read the book written in Dutch, he was startled with the accuracy of the anatomical chart and advised the Domain to purchase the book.
Although Genpaku could not read the book written in Dutch, he was startled with the accuracy of the anatomical chart and advised the Domain to purchase the book.

sen.j: 偶然にも長崎から同じ医学書を持ち帰った前野良沢や、中川淳庵らとともに小塚原刑場（東京都荒川区南千住）で死体の腑分けを実見し、解剖図の正確さに感嘆する。
sen.e: He also had an opportunity to observe himself the dissection of a dead body in Kozuka execution ground (Minamisenju, Arakawa Ward, Tokyo Prefecture) with Ryotaku MAENO who happened to bring back the same medical science book from Nagasaki and Junan NAKAGAWA, and admired how accurate the anatomical chart of the book was.

He also had an opportunity to observe the dissection of a dead body in Kozuka execution ground (Minamisenju, Arakawa Ward, Tokyo Prefecture) with Ryotaku MAENO, who happened to bring back the same medical science book from Nagasaki and Junan NAKAGAWA, and admired how accurate the anatomical chart of the book was.

He also had an opportunity to observe the dissection of a dead body in Kozuka execution ground (Minamisenju, Arakawa Ward, Tokyo Prefecture) with Ryotaku MAENO, who happened to bring back the same medical science book from Nagasaki and Junan NAKAGAWA, and admired how accurate the anatomical chart of the book was.

sen.j: 杉田玄白、前野良沢らは『ターヘル・アナトミア』を和訳し、安永3年（1774年）に『解体新書』として刊行するに至る。
sen.e: Genpaku SUGITA and Ryotaku MAENO translated the "Ontleedkundige Tafelen" and published it as "Kaitai Shinsho (literally, New Book of Anatomy)" in 1774.
Genpaku SUGITA and Ryotaku MAENO translated the "Ontleedkundige Tafelen" and published it as "Kaitai Shinsho (literally, New Book of Anatomy)" in 1774.
Genpaku SUGITA and Ryotaku MAENO translated the "Ontleedkundige Tafelen" and published it as "Kaitai Shinsho (literally, New Book of Anatomy)" in 1774.

sen.j: 安永5年（1776年）藩の中屋敷を出て、近隣の竹本藤兵衛（旗本、500石取）の浜町拝領屋敷500坪のうちに地借し外宅する。
sen.e: In 1776, Genpaku left the second city residence of the Domain and started renting a neighboring Hama-cho residence of 1,650 sq.m., a residence owned by Tobei TAKEMOTO (a bannerman, possessing 139 cubic meters of land).

In 1776, Genpaku left the second city residence of the Domain and started renting a neighboring Hama-cho residence of 1,650 sq.m., a residence owned by Tobei TAKEMOTO (a bannerman, possessing 139 cubic meters of land).

In 1776, Genpaku left the second city residence of the Domain and started renting a neighboring Hama-cho residence of 1,650 sq.m., a residence owned by Tobei TAKEMOTO (hatamoto [a direct vassal of the shogun], with a 500 koku stipend).
sen.cmt: bannerman→hatamoto (a direct vassal of the shogun)用語集に合わせました）, possessing 139 cubic meters of land→with a 500 koku stipend

sen.j: 晩年には回想録として『蘭学事始』を執筆し、後に福澤諭吉により公刊される。
sen.e: In his later years, Genpaku wrote his memoirs, "Rangaku Kotohajime (The Beginning of Dutch Studies)", which was published by Yukichi FUKUZAWA later.
In his later years, Genpaku wrote his memoirs, "Rangaku Kotohajime (The Beginning of Dutch Studies)", which was published by Yukichi FUKUZAWA later.
In his later years, Genpaku wrote his memoirs, "Rangaku Kotohajime (The Beginning of Dutch Studies)," which was published by Yukichi FUKUZAWA later.
sen.cmt: カンマの位置を修正しました。

sen.j: 文化2年（1805年）には、11代将軍徳川家斉に拝謁し、良薬を献上している。
sen.e: In 1805, he was granted an audience with Ienari TOKUGAWA, the 11th shogun, to present the shogun with good medicine.
In 1805, he was granted an audience with Ienari TOKUGAWA, the 11th shogun, to present the shogun with good medicine.
In 1805, he was granted an audience with Ienari TOKUGAWA, the 11th shogun, to present the shogun with good medicine.

sen.j: 文化4年（1807年）に家督を子の伯元に譲り隠居。
sen.e: In 1807, Genpaku handed over the reigns of the family to his son, Hakugen, and retired from the job.
In 1807, Genpaku handed over the reigns of the family to his son, Hakugen, and retired from the job.
In 1807, Genpaku handed over the reigns of the family to his son, Hakugen, and retired from the job.

sen.j: 著書に『形影夜話』ほか。
sen.e: Genpaku's writings include "Keiei Yawa" (memoirs on medical science).
Genpaku's writings include "Keiei Yawa" (memoirs on medical science).
Genpaku's writings include "Keiei Yawa" (memoirs on medical science).

sen.j: 墓所は東京都港区 (東京都)愛宕 (東京都港区)の栄閑院。
sen.e: Genpaku's tomb is in Eikanin of Atago (Minato Ward), Tokyo Prefecture.
Genpaku's tomb is in Eikanin of Atago (Minato Ward), Tokyo Prefecture.
Genpaku's tomb is in Eikanin of Atago (Minato Ward), Tokyo Prefecture.

sen.j: 肖像は石川大浪筆のものが知られ、早稲田大学図書館に所蔵されている。
sen.e: The most famous portrait of Genpaku is the one drawn by Tairo ISHIKAWA, which is now in the possession of the Library of Waseda University.
The most famous portrait of Genpaku is the one drawn by Tairo ISHIKAWA, which is now in the possession of the Library of Waseda University.
The most famous portrait of Genpaku is the one drawn by Tairo ISHIKAWA, which is now in the possession of the Library of Waseda University.

sen.j: 蘭学を世間に知らしめた功績が特に評価されている。
sen.e: Genpaku is the most admired for his achievement in spreading the Western studies across Japan.
Genpaku is the most admired for his achievement in spreading the Western studies across Japan.
Genpaku is the most admired for his achievement in spreading the Western studies across Japan.

sen.j: また後進の育成にも熱心で以後蘭学が発展する基礎を築いた。
sen.e: Also, Genpaku eagerly fostered young doctors and medical researchers, contributing to building a foundation for the Western studies to develop further in future.
Also, Genpaku eagerly fostered young doctors and medical researchers, contributing to building a foundation for the Western studies to develop further in future.
